Title: Object: Design for an Imperial crown to be used at the coronation of the new emperor.
Description: A crown constructed of emblems rests on a bolster-like 'Cushion of Usurpation'. The base or circlet is decorated with cannon and cannon-balls: 'Symbols of Power'. The sides are two dead Turks, inscribed 'Turkish Victims', wearing turban and shawl, their bodies shaped like elongated radishes; two serpents, 'Cunning' and 'Subtilty', extend from the shoulders of the Turks to face each other above a central mask of 'Hypocracy'. Napoleon's face with upturned eyes. Heavy shackles inscribed 'Gallic Liberty' hang from mask and serpents. The centre-piece of the crown, standing on the circlet, is a bottle of 'Poison from Egypt'. From this (l. and r.) two swords both inscribed 'Instrument of Persuasion', slant across (l.) a jewelled turban: 'A Mahometan Turbin' [sic] and (r.) 'A Bishops Mitre', both inscribed 'Religious Convenience'. The apex of the crown is a skull and cross-bones: 'Emblems of Mercy.' September 1804 Hand-coloured etching
Producer name: Print made by: Monogrammist J B
Curator's comments: (Description and comment from M.Dorothy George, 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires in the British Museum', VIII, 1947) See BMSat 10362, &c. For Napoleon's religious opportunism see also BMSat 9973, &c. for the Concordat, BMSat 9866; for 'Turkish victims', BMSat 10062; for 'Poison', BMSat 10063. Listed by Broadley. Copy, J. Ashton, 'English Caricature on Napoleon I', 1884, ii. 23.
Bibliographic references: BM Satires / Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum (10279)
Associated names: Associated with: Napoléon I, Emperor of the French (Napoleon)
